skill.name: go-mod-helper
skill.description: Go module system, dependency management, and project configuration assistance.
skill.summary: Go module system, dependency management, and project configuration assistance.
skill.author: CuriousLearner

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and guidance for Go module management. No executable code, scripts, network calls, file system access, or command execution capabilities.

content.value_statement: Go projects require careful dependency management to maintain stability. This skill provides expert guidance on initializing modules, resolving version conflicts, and configuring Go projects for production.
actual_capabilities: Initialize new Go modules with proper structure
Add, update, and remove Go dependencies
Configure private module access and authentication
Debug module resolution and checksum errors
limitations: Does not execute Go commands directly
Cannot access local files or project structure
Does not modify go.mod or go.sum files
Provides guidance only, not automated fixes

use_cases.title: Set up first Go project
use_cases.description: Initialize a new Go project with proper module structure and best practices for organization.

use_cases.title: Manage complex dependencies
use_cases.description: Resolve version conflicts and configure private module access for enterprise projects.

use_cases.title: Configure CI/CD pipelines
use_cases.description: Set up Go module caching, vendor dependencies, and verify module integrity in CI environments.

prompt_templates.title: Initialize new project
prompt_templates.prompt: @go-mod-helper How do I initialize a new Go module for my project? Show me the standard project structure and go.mod file format.

prompt_templates.title: Add dependency
prompt_templates.prompt: @go-mod-helper I need to add the gin-gonic/gin framework to my project. Show me how to add it with the correct version and verify it works.

prompt_templates.title: Fix version conflicts
prompt_templates.prompt: @go-mod-helper My project has dependency conflicts. How do I use go mod tidy and go mod graph to identify and resolve version issues?

prompt_templates.title: Configure private modules
prompt_templates.prompt: @go-mod-helper I need to configure access to private GitHub packages. Show me how to set up GOPRIVATE and authentication with .netrc or SSH keys.

output_examples.input: How do I initialize a new Go module for a web API project?
output: Create standard structure: cmd/, internal/, pkg/, api/
Use semantic versioning: v1.x.x for stable releases
Run go mod tidy after adding dependencies

best_practices: Always run go mod tidy before committing changes
Keep go.mod and go.sum in version control
Use go mod verify to check dependency integrity before releases
anti_patterns: Manually editing go.sum instead of using go mod tidy
Skipping go.sum verification in CI/CD pipelines
Using loose version constraints without understanding compatibility
Deleting vendor directory without updating dependencies

faq.question: Which Go versions are supported?
faq.answer: Go 1.16 and later are fully supported. Works with Go 1.17+ build constraints syntax and Go 1.18+ workspaces.

faq.question: What are the module cache limits?
faq.answer: Module cache is stored in GOMODCACHE. Default location is $GOPATH/pkg/mod. Clean with go clean -modcache.

faq.question: Can this skill integrate with my IDE?
faq.answer: This skill provides guidance that works with any Go IDE. VS Code, GoLand, and vim all support Go modules natively.

faq.question: Is my code safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-only skill that provides guidance. It does not access, read, or modify any files on your system.

faq.question: Why am I getting checksum mismatch errors?
faq.answer: Checksum mismatches occur when go.sum is outdated or corrupted. Fix by running go clean -modcache, then go mod download and go mod tidy.

faq.question: How does this compare to dep or glide?
faq.answer: Go modules are the official dependency system since Go 1.11. Unlike dep or glide, modules are built into the Go toolchain with native support.
